awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding Generation, Maintenance, and Dynamics of Immune Diversity via Clone-Count Models
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will exploit mathematical and computational approaches to understand the evolution of the diversity of the adaptive immune system. T cells that express different cell surface receptors (or "clonotypes") are produced by the thymus and allow an organism to respond to a broad spectrum of pathogens. How many different surface cell receptors and their total numbers present in the T cell pool are critical quantities that determine an organism's ability to neutralize pathogens. Results of the research have the potential to significantly improve understanding of how the immune repertoire evolves with infections and aging, how it can be more accurately measured, and how it is affected by procedures such as thymic transplantation.  As part of the research the investigators will also foster a series of educational activities involving Cal State-Northridge and UCLA students, including joint seminars, student presentations, and summer projects.

Two representations of counting clonotypes, clone-counts and cell-counts, will be further developed to better measure and quantify the adaptive immune system. Clone-counts describe the number of T cell clonotypes represented by a specific number of cells while cell-counts quantify the number of cells within each clonotype. Mathematical models for T cell populations and T cell diversity typically use one of these two representations and often rely on strong physiological assumptions.  The large number of clonotypes, the constant birth and death of each clonotype, the activation of certain clonotypes upon infection, and the slowing down of thymic output associated with disease and aging all render the quantification and prediction of T cell diversity challenging. By exploiting the mathematical connection between these two representations, the investigators will develop hybrid models of T and B cell components of the immune system applicable under a wider range of physiological conditions.  These hybrid models will be pivotal in extending current models to include important physiological processes such as clonotype proliferation, cellular maturation, and regulation. Finally, hybrid models, both deterministic and stochastic, will facilitate more accurate determination of an organism's immune diversity through small blood samples.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In the final year of this proposal we worked on mathematical modeling and data analysis of hematopoiesis, the process through which the body creates and replenishes cellular components in the blood. The process begins with hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) initiating a cascade of proliferation and differentiation events that generate all mature blood cells in humans and animals. The proper unfoldiing of hemapotoiesis is crucial in maintaining a healthy immune response and  overall homeostasis in the body, and understanding the mechanisms driving it, as well as any irregularities, can help guide clinical treatment, especially those related to bone marrow transplantation and to hinder the development of blood cancers.

Experimentally, hematopoiesis has been studied via stem cell labeling, whereby barcodes or specific viral integration sites are inserted into the genome as "tags" so that subsequent proliferation and differentiation can be followed, since they preserve the original tag. As differentiation and proliferation continue, a population of clones, cells with similar characteristics, can arise and the tagging allows us to follow them. Bench experimentalists have samples the blood of laboratory animals (rhesus macaque in this case)   at discrete time points,  over several years. We thus created a hybrid stochastic-deterministic mathematical model of hematopoiesis to describe the differentiation and proliferation process and its unfolding over time to describe the experimental data. We we were able to infer physiological
parameters (reproduction, differentiation rates and carrying capacity) of hematopoiesis by comparing experimental statistical quantites (mean and variance of the clonal abundances) with the ones predicted by our model.

We also worked on mathematical models of drug addiction, speciflcally on the brain reward system and on the mechanisms leading to relapse, as well as on quantifying mortality rates due to drug overdoses and differentiating among genders, race, drug type, and geography using data from the CDC WONDER.

In previous work performed under this grant we modeled the process of proliferation and differentiation of naive T-cells,  white blood cells which play a fundamental role in the immune response by either destroyong infected cells or signaling the arrival of infections to other immune cells. T-cells are involved in the body's response to pathogens, tumors, and other infectious agents.

T-cells are produced in the bone marrow, mature in the thymus, circulate
through the blood, and migrate to the lymph nodes where they may be presented with different antigen proteins from various pathogens. Naive T cells mature in the thymus where parts of their genes undergo a rearrangement process that leads then to express a single, specific type of cell receptor. It is this process that causes diversity among the T-cell receptors (and the T-cells themselves) which ultimately allows the body to recognize different types of pathogens.

In our mathematical model we consider a birth-death-immigration process to model the formation of T-cell clones, groups of cells that express the same T cell receptor. Specific rearrangement patterns in the thymus might be more frequent than others, resulting in a heterogenous production of T-cell types; similarly, some T-cell types may have different reproduction rates also allowing for heterogeneous proliferation. As a result of either of these processes, the clone abundances of specific T-cell receptors may vary significantly.  The goal of our mathematical model was to determine which one of these mechanisms (heterogeneities in the immigration rates from the thymus or in the proliferation rates) affect the shape of the clone counts that are obtained experimentally. In our model we also include random sampling. From our analysis, using reasonable physiological parameter
values and fitting predicted clone counts to experimentally sampled clone abundances, we show that even modest heterogeneity in proliferation rates can generate the observed clone abundances.

In the year 2022-2023 we published or submitted 5 papers through this grant.
